7F6A16A334C84ED5AF7D7A21FA938022.description: Apply documentation and style conventions systematically in their own work using instructor-specified formats (e.g. MLA, APA)

45EF5B3A67744F75ADEFA1CB7E6DC1FF.description: Use conventions of format, structure, style, design, and documentation, appropriate to the text's rhetorical situation.

82CCE15A53FC4639AD247460FD6CFD53.description: Demonstrate contextually appropriate usage and linguistic structures (e.g. syntax, mechanics) in texts they compose.

03D4CBA3534145609BD9487A203CDD14.description: Use Edited American English in texts they compose.

0A6CAA25B2D24A2B857AFC4971D76F7D.description: Demonstrate understanding that conventions differ across communities, disciplines, and genres.

6ABD4E9AFA5342169E39DE8DB0AAD032.description: Discuss and implement conventions of academic discourse, demonstrate knowledge of various genres and audiences, and use documentation formats.

5829BC409971445C8EA828C249250265.description: Knowledge of Discourse Conventions: Conventions are the formal rules and informal guidelines that define genres; they govern such things as mechanics, usage, spelling, and citation practices. College-level writing often demands adherence to conventions of academic discourse communities. These communities shape readers' and writers' perceptions of correctness or appropriateness.

4B0359B8061043CA85EDFD43BC7C43AD.description: Select and incorporate information from digital and print sources into writing relevant to genre, audience, and purpose.

DF583B82A9404AD8B43C84DA909C1D3A.description: Find information using library databases and/or informal digital networks and distinguish between scholarly and popular sources.

E54AC764F90C4830A4142812C0C78189.description: Demonstrate understanding of the concepts of intellectual property (such as fair use and copyright) that motivate documentation conventions.

24F43A4D05EE474B825C8B7D966E4FD9.description: Evaluate the relevance and trustworthiness of digital sources.

83B8ACE7CE2A45AEBDFAFD51DEE63542.description: Use word processing software to compose and edit texts.

E01BB336657940FA9320E5B320A8045E.description: Demonstrate their ability to use digital and print technologies to produce, evaluate, document, and submit texts.

A076E3CF98634FE1A9191AB752E1D1D6.description: Inquiry and Information Literacy in a Digital Age: Inquiry and information literacy refers to asking questions, developing an understanding of documentation, composing texts grounded in evidence, using a variety of print and digital resources, and producing print and/or digital texts.

463D4355FC2146159256C36CF59E381D.description: Integrate information from course texts and their own ideas into their writing.

F178EE43A5F1449895E74EC729662123.description: Discuss course texts and use reading as a form of inquiry.

EC6C8A3B3E5C4B40BD59D8D09ED8DDBD.description: Demonstrate understanding of vocabulary in texts they read.

0C69C013BBAD4EE0B62DA75477E68B85.description: Distinguish main ideas from supporting details, evaluate claims and evidence, make inferences, and interpret texts.

61E0EF48B7AE410AB796DD70DBA38175.description: Read and comprehend a variety of non-fiction, college-level texts in a variety of genres using active reading processes, including annotation, summary, reflection, response, and evaluation.

2697FEA00E37415DBBCD22A7F166FD69.description: Demonstrate the ability to use active reading strategies and think critically about course materials and concepts.

780E03A476564296ADC7326897897EA3.description: Active Reading and Critical Thinking: Active reading is the process of engaging texts to identify main ideas and supporting evidence, to discern surface-level meaning, and to make logical inferences. Critical thinking refers to the ability to investigate ideas and solve problems through analyzing, interpreting and evaluating information, situations, and texts.

35886674F25B4CC59067EE70E2748C41.description: Adapt voice, tone, and level of formality to a variety of rhetorical situations.

677C9707895448F4B287995EB71A1E75.description: Demonstrate understanding of and use a variety of genres and media to address a range of audiences.

7B891A3D5D85476292D807F4E2F44547.description: Make and discuss composing choices appropriate to purpose, audience, and context.

DE12629985A5479A955AC331AD49243D.description: Analyze the purpose, audience, and context of a wide variety of texts.

A1A44E9DA96C486694BE4B8F04076785.description: Use key rhetorical concepts to discuss writing, reading and speaking occasions.

7DA018D47E494FEC832578B6CBE7B0DA.description: Demonstrate a clear understanding of rhetorical concepts.

5A5FE4A22C65402394AAC0C0542985C9.description: Rhetorical Knowledge: Rhetorical knowledge is the ability to analyze writing, reading, and speaking occasions and then make strategic choices to negotiate the rhetorical situation. Rhetorical knowledge includes the ability to demonstrate command of purpose, audience, and context.

540BC39FB09943938FC01181C8ED686B.description: Edit writing with consideration to surface features, including syntax, usage, punctuation, and spelling appropriate to the rhetorical situation.

367EDD6503C148D090224125A79A2F22.description: Incorporate appropriate, college-level vocabulary in writing.

7304D1E66F9F47B5A03FE3F1E9B32C6C.description: Reflect on assignments and writing processes.

BDE85C2BF53C4C16B8D711B6690D6184.description: Create multiple drafts of an assignment, and revise according to feedback from peers and others to improve development, organization, documentation, and clarity of writing.

5FB250F02EFC4A79980D6D22153D5F5F.description: Use prewriting strategies to plan assignments (e.g., selecting/refining topics, brainstorming, organizing ideas).

6471916DA6E14722BFC5C985C7A9175B.description: Demonstrate the ability to use a recursive writing process to create a variety of academic texts, including at least one essay that incorporates and correctly documents outside sources, producing a total of at least 4500 words (approximately 15 pages) of polished, graded writing.

5789429C88D646EF86EA16B330E510D6.description: Writing Processes: Writers use multiple composing processes to conceptualize, develop, and finalize projects. Composing processes are seldom linear and are also flexible. Successful writers can adapt their composing processes to different genres, contexts, and occasions.
